study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between altered bile acid levels, FXR signaling, and gut microbiota after bariatric surgery, hypothesizing that downstream targets like FGF15/19 mediate its metabolic benefits.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery (RYGB and VSG) effectively induces sustained weight loss and improved glucose metabolism by altering bile acid circulation and composition, with FXR signaling playing a key role. The study suggests that unidentified downstream targets, such as FGF15/19, may be central to these metabolic improvements.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of bariatric surgery effects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the outcomes of robotic sleeve gastrectomy (RSG) versus laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG) in terms of safety and efficacy using a national database.
results_summary: RSG had longer operative times and higher rates of serious morbidity, leaks, and surgical site infections compared to LSG, though 30-day mortality was similar. The study concluded that laparoscopy remains the preferred approach for sleeve gastrectomy.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing sleeve gastrectomy at accredited bariatric centers in 2015, excluding emergent and revisional cases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify anesthetic interventions that improve outcomes and facilitate recovery after bariatric surgery as part of an enhanced recovery after surgery protocol.
results_summary: The study found that implementing specific anesthetic interventions (e.g., carbohydrate loading, opioid minimization, protective ventilation) during pre-, intra-, and postoperative phases is supported by evidence and guidelines to enhance recovery, reduce hospital stay, and lower costs.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether intragastric injections of botulinum toxin type A (BTX-A) could serve as an effective preoperative weight loss method for super-obese patients awaiting bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in weight loss, BMI reduction, or excess weight loss between patients receiving BTX-A injections and the saline control group, concluding that BTX-A was ineffective for preoperative weight loss in super-obese patients. Both groups showed significant weight loss over the study period, but the intervention did not enhance outcomes.
population_specificity: Super-obese patients (n=32)
effective_dosage: 200 units of BTX-A injected into the gastric antrum and body

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of antiretroviral therapy in HIV-infected patients who underwent bariatric surgery, focusing on virologic suppression and obesity control.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery is effective for obesity control in HIV patients, with minimal complications and maintained virologic suppression, though antiretroviral therapy requires careful consideration due to physiologic changes post-surgery.
population_specificity: Adults living with HIV who underwent bariatric surgery.
interactions: Antiretroviral therapy interactions due to physiologic changes post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the intermediate results and factors associated with unsatisfactory weight loss after Laparoscopic Gastric Greater Curvature Plication (LGGCP).
results_summary: The study found a 4.9% postoperative complication rate and modest weight loss (41.9% EBMIL after 3 years), with higher hunger sensation identified as an independent risk factor for unsatisfactory weight loss. GERD prevalence decreased from 46% preoperatively to 34.6% postoperatively, and remission rates for type 2 diabetes and hypertension were 27.8% and 38.3%, respectively.
population_specificity: 48 women and 13 men with an average age of 47.7 years and preoperative BMI of 46.3.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the 4-year effects of preoperative cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) on weight loss, eating behaviors, affective symptoms, and health-related quality of life in bariatric surgery patients.
results_summary: Presurgical CBT was not associated with better long-term outcomes overall, but in patients with minor or considerable symptoms of depression, CBT was linked to lower body weight before and 4 years after surgery. Additional studies are needed to confirm whether CBT should be offered to depressed patients before or after surgery.
population_specificity: Adults (mean age 42.4 years, 70% women) with a mean BMI of 43.5 kg/m² undergoing bariatric surgery.
study_duration: 10 weeks (preoperative) with follow-up at 1 and 4 years post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a very low calorie diet (VLCD) and a low calorie diet (LCD) in reducing liver volume and assessing their impact on biochemical parameters and surgical complications in morbidly obese individuals undergoing bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Both VLCD and LCD significantly reduced hepatic volume, with greater reductions in patients with baseline liver volumes >3L. VLCD led to greater total weight loss (5.8% vs. 4.2%) but had worse tolerance. No differences were found in biochemical parameters, surgical complications, or hospital stay between the two diets.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese individuals undergoing bariatric surgery (n=86).
effective_dosage: Not specified (VLCD and LCD protocols detailed but exact caloric values not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current knowledge on new treatment options, including Bariatric Surgery, for pediatric obesity.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that Bariatric Surgery is promising for extremely obese adolescents, but long-term studies are needed to better define its exact role.
population_specificity: Extremely obese adolescents

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the 10-year outcomes of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass between Medicare beneficiaries and non-Medicare patients to determine if there were differences in weight loss and comorbidity resolution.
results_summary: The study found that Roux-en-Y gastric bypass provided similar benefits in terms of weight loss and comorbidity resolution for both Medicare and non-Medicare patients at the 10-year follow-up, supporting expanded Medicare coverage for the procedure. Medicare patients had a higher preoperative BMI but achieved comparable outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass with 10-year follow-up at a single medical center from 1985 to 2005, stratified by Medicare insurance status (n=617, 19% Medicare).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between obesity and chronic kidney disease (CKD), particularly how severe obesity affects glomerular filtration rate (GFR).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about Bariatric Surgery's effects, only noting that obesity worsens CKD progression.
population_specificity: Patients with severe obesity (stages II and III, BMI >35 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to update evidence-based guidelines for metabolic and bariatric surgery (MBS) in adolescents, evaluating its safety, efficacy, and appropriateness for severe obesity treatment.
results_summary: The study found that MBS is safe and effective for adolescents with severe obesity, particularly those with class II obesity and comorbidities or class III obesity. Early intervention can reduce persistent obesity and end-organ damage from long-standing comorbidities.
population_specificity: Adolescents with severe obesity (class II or III) and specific comorbidities, including those with cognitive disabilities, treated mental illness, or eating disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare perioperative complication rates and short-term outcomes of patients undergoing single-stage conversion from gastric band to either Roux-en-Y gastric bypass or laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy.
results_summary: Conversion to sleeve gastrectomy showed a better perioperative safety profile with no readmissions or reinterventions compared to gastric bypass, but both procedures provided comparable early excess weight loss at 1 year (52.1% vs. 57.1%).
population_specificity: Patients in the UK who underwent single-stage conversion from gastric band to either gastric bypass (113) or sleeve gastrectomy (28) between 2009 and 2014.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between bariatric surgery and the incidence of microvascular complications in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was associated with a significantly lower risk of incident microvascular disease (16.9% vs. 34.7% in nonsurgical patients) and reduced cumulative incidence of diabetic neuropathy, nephropathy, and retinopathy compared to usual care.
population_specificity: Adults aged 19 to 79 years with type 2 diabetes mellitus who underwent bariatric surgery (n=4024) matched with nonsurgical participants (n=11059).
study_duration: Median follow-up of 4.3 years for both surgical and nonsurgical patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of calcium citrate versus calcium carbonate on parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels in RYGB patients with elevated PTH.
results_summary: Both calcium formulations had a neutral effect on PTH levels, with no significant difference between them. However, calcium citrate significantly reduced certain bone turnover markers compared to calcium carbonate.
population_specificity: Thirty-nine RYGB-operated patients with elevated PTH levels and normal calcium and vitamin D levels.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the prevalence of Helicobacter Pylori (HP) infection and identify predictive factors in patients with class II and III obesity volunteering for bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found a 22% prevalence of HP infection, associated with social precariousness and higher vitamin B levels, but no association with metabolic parameters, liver enzymes, or vitamin deficiencies. The findings were insufficient to define patients who do not require HP screening before bariatric surgery.
population_specificity: Patients with class II and III obesity (median age 43, 81% female) volunteering for bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the regulation of myostatin in obesity and its potential associations with metabolic markers and insulin resistance/sensitivity indices.
results_summary: The study found that circulating active myostatin concentration was increased in obese individuals compared to lean controls, but myostatin adipose tissue expression did not differ. Muscle myostatin gene expression correlated with metabolic gene expression.
population_specificity: Twenty-eight severely obese non-diabetic patients and a sex- and age-matched lean and overweight control group (n=22).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate trends in utilization, clinical characteristics, and inpatient outcomes of bariatric surgery among individuals with knee osteoarthritis from 2005 to 2014.
results_summary: Utilization of bariatric surgery remained consistent (~3,300 procedures annually), with a shift from laparoscopic Roux-en-Y to sleeve gastrectomy. In-hospital mortality remained low (0.0-0.1%), and costs for some procedures decreased, while safety and efficacy were maintained despite increasing patient age and comorbidities.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese adults with clinically documented knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effects of bariatric surgery on nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) and its potential to improve cardiovascular dysfunction.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery results in significant improvement or resolution of NASH, alongside standard obesity treatments like lifestyle interventions and FDA-approved drugs.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity and nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential role of bariatric surgery in improving immunity in obese and type 2 diabetes (T2D) patients, given its success in treating obesity and improving T2D outcomes.
results_summary: The study suggests bariatric surgery is the most effective treatment for obesity and the only method that sustains substantial improvement in T2D, potentially also enhancing immune function in these patients.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity and type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2D).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current knowledge on the effectiveness of deep brain stimulation (DBS) of the nucleus accumbens (NAC) for treating morbid obesity.
results_summary: Animal studies suggest a beneficial effect of high-frequency NAC-DBS on body weight, and limited human case reports also show positive outcomes, but optimal stimulation parameters and electrode placement remain unestablished.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients (human and animal studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the considerations and best approaches for managing cirrhotic patients undergoing bariatric surgery, particularly in the context of NAFLD and NASH-related complications.
results_summary: The study highlights that bariatric surgery is associated with positive outcomes like reversal of type 2 diabetes and reduced all-cause mortality, but also notes increased risks for patients with NAFLD-related cirrhosis, emphasizing the need for careful evaluation of liver function and surgical factors.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients, particularly those with NAFLD, NASH, or NASH-related cirrhosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effect on weight loss between a long biliopancreatic limb Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (LBP-GB) and a standard RYGB (S-GB).
results_summary: The LBP-GB group showed significantly higher excess weight loss (%EWL) in the first years post-surgery compared to the S-GB group, but no long-term difference in total weight loss (%TWL) was observed after 4 years. The advantage of LBP-GB was modest but suggested potential for future RYGB design improvements.
population_specificity: 146 patients with morbid obesity.
effective_dosage: LBP-GB (BPL 150 cm, alimentary limb 75 cm) vs. S-GB (BPL 75 cm, alimentary limb 150 cm).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review established risk factors, complications, and long-term consequences of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) for both mothers and offspring.
results_summary: The study critically reviewed data on GDM risk factors, pregnancy and birth complications, and long-term health outcomes for mothers and offspring, suggesting that proper management could mitigate adverse effects.
population_specificity: High-risk ethnic groups and individuals with a body mass index ≥ 25 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the prevalence and predictors of weight regain after bariatric surgery and evaluate the utility of behavioral and pharmacotherapeutic interventions to address it.
results_summary: The study found that weight regain is common after bariatric surgery, and while lifestyle interventions are fundamental, their efficacy is limited and can be enhanced by pharmacotherapy, particularly when initiated at weight plateau. Further prospective studies are needed to determine optimal combinations and timing of therapies.
population_specificity: Individuals who underwent bariatric surgery (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a single low-dose administration of ketamine after bariatric surgery could improve pain and mood scores in the immediate postoperative period.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in visual analogue pain scores between ketamine and placebo groups, but ketamine significantly improved affective pain scores by postoperative day 2 compared to placebo, which only showed improvement by day 7.
population_specificity: 100 patients undergoing laparoscopic gastric bypass and gastrectomy at a tertiary care hospital.
effective_dosage: 0.4 mg/kg ketamine as a single dose.
study_duration: Single administration in the postanaesthesia care unit.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if bariatric surgery reduces foot pain in obese individuals and whether BMI or body composition predicts changes in foot pain.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was significantly associated with reduced foot pain at 6-month follow-up, while higher baseline fat mass index predicted increased pain. The surgery group lost a mean of 24.3 kg, whereas the control group gained 1.2 kg.
population_specificity: Obese individuals (mean BMI ~44.8-47.9 kg/m²) with foot pain awaiting bariatric surgery (38 female, 7 male, mean age 45.7 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether exercise is a critical factor for long-term weight loss maintenance and lasting remission of type 2 diabetes in bariatric surgery patients.
results_summary: The study suggests that exercise is a feasible and clinically effective adjunct therapy for bariatric surgery patients, potentially aiding long-term weight loss maintenance and diabetes remission, though weight regain and diabetes relapse remain issues for some.
population_specificity: Bariatric surgery patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether post-operative high flow nasal oxygen therapy (HFNO) reduces respiratory complications in bariatric surgery patients.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of HFNO on respiratory complications or weight loss outcomes. The study is described as a pilot, suggesting preliminary data collection.
population_specificity: Patients with BMI > 30 kg/m² undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the benefits and harms of bariatric surgery on kidney function in obese adults, including those with and without chronic kidney disease (CKD) or kidney transplants.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery significantly decreased serum creatinine levels and tended to normalize glomerular filtration rate (GFR) across different categories of renal impairment, including hyperfiltration and CKD patients. The study included 23 cohort studies with 3015 participants, showing positive effects on kidney function.
population_specificity: Obese adults (non-CKD, CKD, or transplanted patients) who underwent bariatric surgery for weight loss.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review evidence for outcomes following intentional weight loss, including bariatric surgery, in patients with obesity and heart failure.
results_summary: Observational studies on bariatric surgery suggested a trend of improvement in left ventricular function, quality of life, and exercise capacity, though the studies were small, heterogeneous, and had a high risk of bias.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity and heart failure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of weight loss on endothelial function in patients with and without obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) within the first 6 months after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) improved anthropometric, bioimpedance, and endothelial function results in both groups, but patients with OSA showed a 2.5% lower improvement in endothelial function compared to those without OSA. The study also noted significant clinical improvement in OSA symptoms post-surgery.
population_specificity: 56 patients (homogeneously divided into groups with and without OSA) undergoing RYGB at a university hospital in Brazil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of robotic bariatric surgery compared to conventional laparoscopic surgery in treating obesity in Brazil.
results_summary: Robotic bariatric surgery showed comparable safety and efficacy to laparoscopic surgery, with longer operative times but similar postoperative outcomes, including pain, nausea, and comorbidity control. Minor complications like incisional hernias occurred in two cases, and one patient required ICU admission due to pre-existing cardiopathy.
population_specificity: 45 patients (34 female, mean age 39.44 years, mean BMI 41.26 kg/m²) undergoing robotic bariatric surgery in Brazil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a multidisciplinary approach to weight management in patients with type 2 diabetes (T2D) and obesity in real-world clinical practice.
results_summary: The study found that multidisciplinary weight management programs in clinical settings lead to long-term weight loss for up to 5 years and are associated with improved cardiovascular risk factors in patients with T2D and obesity.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes (T2D) who are overweight or obese.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the metabolic outcomes, particularly glycaemic control, of laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) versus sleeve gastrectomy (SG) in overweight and obese patients with or without type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: RYGB was more effective than SG in improving weight loss and short- to mid-term glycaemic and lipid metabolism control in patients with and without T2DM, showing lower fasting glucose levels and HbA1c at various follow-up intervals. No significant differences were found in fasting insulin levels or HOMA indices between the two procedures.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese patients with or without T2DM (1,132 patients across 16 RCTs).
study_duration: Follow-up periods ranged from 12 to 60 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate predictors for bariatric surgery in everyday clinical practice among patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and obesity.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery was rarely used (0.07% of patients) and was associated with favorable 2-year outcomes. Patients who underwent surgery were predominantly female, younger, had a longer diabetes duration, and higher BMI compared to non-surgery controls.
population_specificity: Patients with T2DM from Germany and Austria, treated by bariatric surgery or non-surgery controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between bariatric surgery and obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) severity, focusing on how different respiratory event scoring criteria affect this relationship.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery led to reductions in BMI and AHI, but OSA persisted in most subjects at follow-up. High heterogeneity between studies was noted, primarily due to baseline AHI and follow-up duration, and insufficient data existed to assess the impact of different respiratory event scoring criteria.
population_specificity: Individuals undergoing bariatric surgery with OSA (specific demographics not detailed).
study_duration: Follow-up duration varied (not specified in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current evidence and expert opinions on long-term nutritional care and complications following bariatric surgery, including strategies to improve follow-up rates and patient outcomes.
results_summary: The study highlights significant long-term complications of bariatric surgery, such as anemia, bone fractures, and neurological/psychological issues, while emphasizing the need for improved follow-up, psychological care, and patient-centered approaches to maximize benefits and minimize adverse effects.
population_specificity: Patients with classes II and III obesity who underwent bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the current evidence on bariatric surgery's effects on fertility, pregnancy outcomes, and nutritional needs, while identifying gaps in knowledge.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery is effective for weight loss and improving fertility but poses challenges in diagnosing gestational diabetes and lacks sufficient data on nutrient supplementation during pregnancy. Current guidelines recommend delaying conception for 12-24 months post-surgery, but more research is needed.
population_specificity: Women of reproductive age who have undergone bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of sleeve gastrectomy (SG) and Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) on bile acids (BAs) and fibroblast growth factor19 (FGF19) and their associations with metabolic improvements in type 2 diabetes (T2DM) and obesity.
results_summary: Both SG and RYGB resulted in similar weight loss and diabetes remission rates. Greater increases in fasting and prandial levels of total, secondary, and unconjugated BAs were observed after RYGB than SG, and these changes correlated with improvements in HbA1c but not weight. Changes in prandial FGF19 were negatively associated with HbA1c and visceral fat.
population_specificity: 61 obese patients with type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze changes in food intake during the first postoperative year of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus or glycemic alterations.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in glycemic levels, reduced energy and macronutrient intake, decreased consumption of alcoholic beverages and soft drinks, and increased fiber intake and diet fractionation. Micronutrient intake for glycemic control was higher up to six months postoperatively, but dietary patterns tended to revert toward preoperative habits by one year.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus or glycemic alterations undergoing Roux-en-Y gastric bypass.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between individual variations in body fat distribution and the metabolic heterogeneity of obesity, as well as its associated cardiovascular risk.
results_summary: The abstract does not present specific findings on bariatric surgery but discusses the complex relationship between obesity and cardiovascular disease, emphasizing the role of body fat distribution in metabolic risk.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion on obesity and cardiovascular risk)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the influence of gastrointestinal diseases and surgical effects, including bariatric surgery, on drug absorption and distribution.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings on bariatric surgery but highlights a gap in understanding how gastrointestinal diseases and surgeries affect drug delivery. It suggests a need for further research to uncover clinical implications.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of gastrointestinal diseases and surgeries)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether intravenous iron supplementation postoperatively in post-bariatric abdominoplasty could increase blood haemoglobin concentrations compared to oral iron supplementation.
results_summary: Intravenous iron increased haemoglobin concentrations at 56 days post-operatively and reduced iron deficiency without adverse events, though the minimum clinically relevant difference was not reached. Oral iron supplementation was associated with gastrointestinal side effects (constipation, diarrhoea, nausea).
population_specificity: Women aged 18-55 years who underwent post-bariatric abdominoplasty after vertical banded gastroplasty with Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, with grade III contour deformity and BMI <32 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of two respiratory interventions (positive pressure and inspiratory load exercises) on lung function, inspiratory muscle strength, and atelectasis prevalence after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Both interventions preserved expiratory reserve volume and tidal volume, with a low atelectasis rate (5%). The inspiratory load group maintained inspiratory muscle strength and respiratory muscle resistance better than the positive pressure group.
population_specificity: Subjects submitted to bariatric surgery.
effective_dosage: Positive pressure group: one hour of positive pressure at two levels plus conventional respiratory physiotherapy twice immediately post-op and three times daily on the first post-op day. Inspiratory load group: six sets of 15 repetitions of linear inspiratory pressure exercises plus conventional respiratory physiotherapy at the same frequency.
study_duration: Interventions were applied twice in the immediate postoperative period and three times on the first postoperative day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of bariatric surgery in the prevention and management of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), particularly its long-term histological impact.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery has a favorable long-term impact on NAFLD histology but should currently be restricted to patients with morbid obesity due to surgical morbidity. Cardiovascular disease remains the leading cause of death in NAFLD patients, and most will not develop liver-related complications.
population_specificity: Patients with morbid obesity and NAFLD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the recurrence rate after ventral hernia repair and the incidence of prosthetic infection during bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study reviewed 11 studies, finding that ventral hernias were treated by simple suture, synthetic mesh, and biological mesh, with a mean defect size of 18 cm. Outcomes focused on recurrence rates and prosthetic infection incidence, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery with ventral hernias.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the safety and impact of bariatric surgery (RYGB, SG, AGB) on HIV disease markers (CD4 cell count, viral load) and HAART absorption in HIV-infected individuals.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was found to be safe in HIV-infected individuals with no adverse impact on HIV disease progression. No difference in HIV-related outcomes was observed between SG and RYGB.
population_specificity: HIV-infected individuals undergoing bariatric surgery (RYGB, SG, AGB).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize interventions for treating hypothalamic obesity (CP-HO) related to craniopharyngiomas, focusing on pharmacotherapy and bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The review found limited evidence supporting bariatric surgery for select CP-HO patients, with gastric bypass being a potential option, but the overall evidence base was low quality and lacked sufficient data for meta-analysis.
population_specificity: Patients with hypothalamic obesity (CP-HO) due to craniopharyngiomas and their treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare mid-term lipid profile outcomes between laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (LRYGB) and laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG) in bariatric surgery patients and identify factors associated with lipid disturbance remission.
results_summary: LRYGB showed superior remission rates for low-density lipoprotein cholesterol and hypertriglyceridemia compared to LSG at 5 years, with no differences in high-density lipoprotein cholesterol normalization. Male sex, absence of statins, and LRYGB technique were associated with better lipid outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with severe obesity undergoing bariatric surgery at Hospital del Mar, Barcelona, from January 2005 to January 2012.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of bariatric surgery on periodontal status through a systematic review of observational studies.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in clinical attachment level, gingival index, percentage of bleeding sites, or pocket probing depth before and after bariatric surgery, but the plaque index improved post-surgery.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relationship between obesity and perioperative/postoperative outcomes in colorectal cancer patients, including differences between hospitals performing bariatric surgery and those that did not.
results_summary: Obesity was identified as a significant risk factor for higher postoperative morbidity, prolonged hospitalization, and increased readmission rates in colorectal cancer patients. No differences were observed between hospitals performing bariatric surgery and those that did not.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing colorectal cancer surgery in the Netherlands (2009–2016), categorized by BMI (underweight, normal weight, overweight, and obesity classes I–III).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of metabolic and bariatric surgery as a treatment for obesity and its associated comorbidities, particularly cardiovascular diseases.
results_summary: The study found that metabolic and bariatric surgery is the most effective and durable treatment for obesity, significantly alleviating or eliminating comorbidities like type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and dyslipidemia, while improving quality of life and overall survival with low complication risks.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity, particularly those with severe obesity and related cardiovascular risk factors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety profile of intragastric balloons (IGBs) with laparoscopic bariatric surgery (LBS) using a large database analysis.
results_summary: The study found that IGBs had a higher 30-day adverse event rate compared to LBS, primarily due to a four-times higher nonoperative reintervention rate, driven by early balloon removal. LBS demonstrated a better safety profile in this analysis.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric procedures (144,627 LBS and 781 IGB) from 791 centers in the United States and Canada.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare nutritional deficiencies (vitamin D, B12, albumin) and fracture risk in severely obese patients after Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) or sleeve gastrectomy (SG) versus a conservatively treated control group.
results_summary: Vitamin D, B12, and albumin levels remained within recommended ranges post-surgery, but B12 was higher in SG patients. Bariatric surgery groups had a higher cumulative fracture risk compared to the control group, with age, surgery type, and lower BMI increasing fracture risk.
population_specificity: Severely obese patients who underwent RYGB (253) or SG (142) between 2007-2010, compared to a control group (199) receiving lifestyle intervention (2002-2006).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG) in LVAD patients with morbid obesity as a bridge to cardiac transplantation.
results_summary: The study found no perioperative deaths, with 37% of patients achieving BMI <35 and receiving cardiac transplantation, and an additional 27% achieving BMI <35. LSG was deemed safe and effective for lowering BMI in this population.
population_specificity: Patients with morbid obesity and end-stage heart failure requiring LVAD support.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of obesity and bariatric surgery on osteoarthritis and total joint arthroplasty outcomes, as well as the financial and ethical implications of using bariatric surgery for risk reduction before arthroplasty.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings but indicates that the study explores the unclear impact of bariatric surgery on outcomes after total joint arthroplasty in morbidly obese patients, along with financial and ethical considerations.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients undergoing or considering total joint arthroplasty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether preperitoneal anesthesia with bupivacaine would reduce pain and opioid consumption after bariatric surgery and lower the incidence of chronic postsurgical pain.
results_summary: The study found that preperitoneal bupivacaine significantly reduced postoperative opioid consumption and pain scores in the first hour and at 6 hours post-surgery, and it lowered the incidence of chronic postsurgical pain from 40% to 13% one year after surgery.
population_specificity: Adults undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery.
study_duration: 24 hours post-surgery for acute outcomes, 1 year for chronic pain assessment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current clinical knowledge and evidence regarding one-anastomosis gastric bypass as a primary treatment for obesity or metabolic disease.
results_summary: The review synthesizes expert opinion and published peer-reviewed evidence but does not establish a standard of care. It addresses inquiries about the procedure's role in treating obesity or metabolic conditions.
population_specificity: Patients, physicians, society members, hospitals, and others inquiring about one-anastomosis gastric bypass.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the accuracy of predictive equations for estimating total energy expenditure (TEE) in class III obese women before and after bariatric surgery, using doubly labeled water (DLW) as the reference.
results_summary: The study found that none of the predictive equations accurately estimated TEE across all periods, but Harris and Benedict x MET and DRI equations provided acceptable accuracy. Patients showed 65% excess weight loss and a 17% reduction in body fat mass after one year.
population_specificity: Twenty class III obese women (age: 29.4 ± 5.1 years; BMI: 44.9 ± 2.5 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the development of multireceptor agonists as a potential alternative to bariatric surgery for treating metabolic dysfunction, focusing on the synergistic effects of GLP-1, GIP, and glucagon.
results_summary: The study highlights that bariatric surgery remains the most potent and sustainable treatment for metabolic dysfunction, but it reviews the potential of multireceptor agonists to enhance GLP-1's effects by targeting multiple tissues, such as the brain and pancreatic β cells, for improved efficacy.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of preclinical and clinical findings).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) followed by supervised physical training on physical capacity.
results_summary: The study found that RYGB resulted in significant weight loss and reduced obesity-related morbidity and mortality, while physical training improved aerobic capacity.
population_specificity: 60 participants eligible for RYGB.
effective_dosage: Two weekly physical training sessions for 26 weeks (INT group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the bidirectional relationship between metabolic syndrome (MetS) and hypogonadism (HG) and the effects of treatments, including bariatric surgery, on testosterone levels and metabolic improvements.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was found to significantly increase testosterone levels in obese men (8.73 nmol/L increase) compared to a low-calorie diet (2.87 nmol/L increase). The study also noted improvements in metabolic derangements associated with MetS in subjects treated with testosterone, though these results were not conclusive.
population_specificity: Obese men with metabolic syndrome and hypogonadism.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the quality and transferability of cost-effectiveness studies of bariatric surgery to Switzerland and adapt these findings to the Swiss healthcare context.
results_summary: Most studies found bariatric surgery to be cost-saving or cost-effective compared to conventional treatment, particularly for patients with BMI >35kg/m², with gastric bypass showing superior efficacy but higher costs than gastric banding. Adaptation of cost data provided an approximation of cost-effectiveness for Switzerland, though not exact ICERs.
population_specificity: Patients with BMI >35kg/m² and some with BMI <35kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of type 2 diabetes mellitus and insulin therapy on non-alcoholic fatty liver disease in morbidly obese patients undergoing bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Type 2 diabetes mellitus was an independent risk factor for severe steatosis and fibrosis. Insulin therapy was associated with non-alcoholic steatohepatitis and fibrosis in the overall patient group but not when only diabetic patients were analyzed.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically assess the quality of patient-reported outcome measures for Quality of Life in bariatric surgery and body contouring surgery.
results_summary: The study identified 24 instruments, with none meeting all quality requirements (category A). The BODY-Q showed the strongest evidence for content validity in both BS and BCS, while most instruments were minimally validated (category D).
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery or body contouring surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of bariatric surgery as a long-term treatment for severe or moderate obesity with co-morbid conditions when non-surgical approaches fail.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery is the most effective and long-term treatment for severe obesity or moderate obesity complicated by co-morbid conditions, outperforming non-surgical approaches. It positions bariatric surgery as the third step in a three-tiered intensification of care approach for weight management.
population_specificity: Individuals with severe obesity or moderate obesity complicated by co-morbid conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of bariatric surgery on hyperuricemia and gout in obese patients and suggest a perioperative approach to prevent gouty attacks.
results_summary: Weight loss from bariatric surgery reduces hyperuricemia in the long term, but acute gout attacks are common shortly after surgery in patients with pre-existing gout. A perioperative approach involving hydration, physical activity, urate-lowering drugs, and anti-inflammatory medications is recommended.
population_specificity: Obese patients with hyperuricemia or gout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of a probiotic/prebiotic blend (LactoWise®) on weight loss, blood pressure, and clinical lab values in morbidly obese patients undergoing laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG).
results_summary: The study found that the probiotic/prebiotic blend led to greater weight loss at 6 weeks (but not at 3 months), significant reductions in triglycerides, LDL, and AST compared to placebo, suggesting potential metabolic benefits for LSG patients.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients (mean BMI 46.6 ± 8.2 kg/m², mean age 47.7 ± 12.4 years) undergoing laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy.
effective_dosage: LactoWise® group received 4.5 billion live cells of bacillus coagulans and 300 mg galactomannans daily; placebo group received 600 mg calcium citrate (126 mg elemental calcium) daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of bariatric surgery, specifically laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy, in managing obesity among kidney transplant candidates and recipients.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery can result in significant weight loss with reduced morbidity, but many patients decline this treatment. The best approach for managing obese transplant candidates and recipients remains unresolved.
population_specificity: Kidney transplant candidates and recipients, including potential living kidney donors, with obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review existing literature on body image changes before and after bariatric surgery and subsequent body contouring procedures to inform future clinical research and care.
results_summary: The review found general improvements in certain aspects of body image post-bariatric surgery, but highlighted a lack of systematic examination of body image domains across the surgical journey, with significant variation in reporting standards and few studies addressing body contouring.
population_specificity: Individuals seeking or having undergone bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to familiarize radiologists with typical post-operative findings and potential complications of bariatric surgery procedures (RYGB, LAGB, SG) on UGI series and CT.
results_summary: The study presented typical post-operative imaging findings for RYGB, LAGB, and SG, along with an overview of potential complications and interpretation pitfalls. It did not report clinical outcomes or efficacy of the procedures.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent bariatric surgery (RYGB, LAGB, SG).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of obesity and weight loss interventions, including bariatric surgery, on skeletal health.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery's skeletal effects vary by procedure type, with malabsorptive procedures linked to higher short-term adverse effects on bone health. Obesity generally has a positive effect on skeletal strength, but weight loss interventions may lead to bone loss over time.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity undergoing weight loss interventions, including bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether intramuscular vitamin D supplementation could effectively address hypovitaminosis D in BPD/DS patients who remained deficient despite oral supplementation.
results_summary: A single 600,000 IU cholecalciferol injection significantly elevated vitamin D levels at 1 and 6 months and normalized PTH levels, while oral supplementation alone failed to correct deficiencies. The treatment was simple and highly effective, particularly in low UV-B exposure conditions.
population_specificity: Twenty BPD/DS patients approximately 4 years post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a model of body image concepts and dimensions in bariatric surgery patients to facilitate systematic clinical measurement before and after surgery.
results_summary: The study identified factors influencing body image in bariatric surgery patients, summarized eight measures, and proposed a new definition. The model aims to encourage clinical measurement of body image at multiple post-surgery time points.
population_specificity: Bariatric surgery patients (before and after surgery)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between obesity and urolithiasis, including the role of bariatric surgery in hyperoxaluria and oxalate nephropathy.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery is associated with hyperoxaluria and oxalate nephropathy, potentially increasing the risk of renal stone disease. Obesity-related nephrolithiasis may require weight loss as primary treatment, but the optimal approach to minimize stone risk remains undetermined.
population_specificity: Obese patients with or at risk of urolithiasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the existing information on the link between bariatric surgery and esophageal disorders, focusing on GERD and motor dysfunctions.
results_summary: The review found that restrictive procedures like LAGB and LSG are associated with de novo or worsened GERD, with LAGB showing the highest frequency of esophageal motor disorders. RYGB was identified as the best procedure for improving GERD symptoms and preserving esophageal function.
population_specificity: Patients with morbid obesity undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if the Cleveland Clinic Behavioral Rating Scale (CCBRS) could predict postoperative outcomes such as weight loss, quality of life, depression, anxiety, and alcohol use after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that higher preoperative CCBRS ratings predicted better postoperative outcomes, including improved quality of life (SF-36 scores), reduced depression (PHQ-9 scores), and lower alcohol use (AUDIT scores), though anxiety (GAD-7 scores) did not change significantly. The CCBRS social support rating also predicted higher postoperative excess weight loss.
population_specificity: 179 patients (113 Roux-en-Y gastric bypass and 66 sleeve gastrectomy) in a U.S. hospital setting.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (behavioral assessment tool, not a dosage-based intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of bariatric surgery for weight loss and diabetes remission compared to lifestyle interventions and anti-obesity medications, while also exploring the potential of new polypharmacological drugs.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was found to be effective for sustained weight loss and diabetes remission, though restricted to extremely obese patients. New polypharmacological drugs combining multiple hormone agonisms showed superior preclinical efficacy compared to existing medications.
population_specificity: Extremely obese individuals (subset of patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the relative effectiveness of weight loss treatments, including bariatric surgery, in young patients (<21 years) with obesity.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery resulted in high short/medium-term weight loss, with a pooled estimate of 14.04 kg/m². The study meta-analyzed 83 eligible studies out of 16,372 identified.
population_specificity: Young people (<21 years) with obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine hepatobiliary complications related to hypoalimentation, including liver dysfunction following bariatric surgery, and the management of intestinal failure-associated liver disease (IFALD).
results_summary: The study found that liver dysfunction can occur after bariatric surgery due to hypoalimentation, and treatment of the underlying condition may improve liver function. It also highlighted that long-term parenteral nutrition (PN) can lead to liver enzyme abnormalities and IFALD, requiring systematic management.
population_specificity: Patients with hypoalimentation conditions (e.g., anorexia nervosa, obesity malnutrition, post-bariatric surgery liver disease) and those receiving long-term PN for intestinal failure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether previous abdominal surgery influences the course and outcomes of laparoscopic bariatric surgery, specifically focusing on operative time, complications, and long-term weight loss.
results_summary: The study found that previous abdominal surgery prolonged operative time for RYGB and hospitalization duration but did not affect long-term weight loss outcomes or complication rates. No significant differences were observed in SG cases.
population_specificity: 1706 patients who underwent laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (SG) or Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) at seven referral bariatric centers in Poland.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the safety and preliminary efficacy of bariatric arterial embolization (BAE) as an alternative treatment for obesity, particularly for patients who are obese but not morbidly obese.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that bariatric surgery, while a standard treatment, has high morbidity and cost burdens with limited outcomes, whereas BAE shows potential based on its safety and preliminary efficacy profiles. The review discusses up-to-date clinical data and future directions for BAE.
population_specificity: Patients who are obese but not morbidly obese.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of different bariatric procedures in adolescents using electronic health record data.
results_summary: Adolescents undergoing sleeve gastrectomy (SG) and Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) showed greater declines in BMI at 1- and 3-year follow-ups, while laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding was significantly less effective for BMI reduction.
population_specificity: Predominantly female (79%) and White (66%) adolescents with severe obesity (mean BMI 49.8 kg/m²).
study_duration: Follow-up periods at 1, 3, and 5 years post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to advocate for expanded insurance coverage of bariatric surgery as part of a weight-centric approach to prevent and manage type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study highlights the need for broader insurance coverage of bariatric surgery and other obesity treatments to prevent the costly complications of type 2 diabetes, emphasizing the irony of funding disease management over prevention.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion on obesity and type 2 diabetes management)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cefazolin concentrations in blood and fatty tissue were adequate for antibiotic prophylaxis in obese patients undergoing sleeve gastrectomy.
results_summary: The study found that after a 4 g dose of cefazolin, concentrations in fatty tissue exceeded the target threshold (4 μg/g) in both moderately and severely obese patients, suggesting effective prophylaxis. No significant differences were observed between the two BMI groups.
population_specificity: Obese patients (Group A: BMI 40-50 kg/m²; Group B: BMI >50 kg/m²) undergoing sleeve gastrectomy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to outline the current landscape of endoscopic treatments, including bariatric surgery, for obesity and diabetes, focusing on clinical evidence, efficacy, safety, and mechanisms of action.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery is an established treatment for obesity and type 2 diabetes, with impressive results in weight loss and glycemic control. Endoscopic devices are emerging as potential alternatives or adjuncts to surgery.
population_specificity: Not specified (general obesity and type 2 diabetes population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the necessity and legal implications of bariatric surgery as the only viable treatment for extreme morbid obesity (EMO) cases where death is imminent without intervention.
results_summary: The study highlights that bariatric surgery is the sole effective treatment for EMO patients, despite its high-risk nature, and proposes legal measures to address enablement of food addiction to improve treatment compliance and outcomes.
population_specificity: Individuals with extreme morbid obesity (EMO), characterized by imminent death risk, impeded mobility, and high dependency on caregivers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the controversial effects of bariatric surgery on fertility and the potential for preserving fertility after major gastrointestinal operations.
results_summary: The study highlights that obesity reduces fertility by 20%, but the impact of bariatric surgery on fertility remains unclear. However, fertility preservation is possible after certain major gastrointestinal surgeries if patient age permits and reproductive organs are not resected.
population_specificity: Patients capable of procreation undergoing treatment for gastrointestinal diseases, including chronic inflammatory diseases, intestinal cancer, and hereditary conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of endoscopic treatment as a supplementary strategy for obesity management in specific patient groups where medical therapy or surgery is insufficient, contraindicated, or high-risk.
results_summary: The study found that endoscopic treatment can benefit obese patients in three scenarios: non-morbid obesity where medical therapy fails, morbid obesity when surgery is rejected or high-risk, and superobesity to reduce surgical risks. It highlights the need for multidisciplinary management and standardized requirements for bariatric endoscopy units.
population_specificity: Patients with grade-II overweight, non-morbid obesity, morbid obesity, or superobesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of T lymphocyte subpopulations in severe obesity and their potential contribution to microvascular alterations.
results_summary: The study found that severely obese patients had reduced Treg lymphocytes and increased CD4+ effector memory T cells compared to controls, suggesting these changes might contribute to microvascular damage.
population_specificity: 32 severely obese patients undergoing bariatric surgery, 24 normotensive lean subjects, and 12 hypertensive lean subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential of bariatric surgery for weight loss and improvement in liver histology in adolescents with NAFLD.
results_summary: Recent studies indicate promising results for bariatric surgery in adolescents with NAFLD, showing benefits in weight loss and liver histology improvement. However, the studies are limited by small sample sizes and heterogeneous outcome assessments.
population_specificity: Adolescents with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether magnesium sulfate could effectively manage postoperative pain and reduce opioid consumption in patients undergoing sleeve gastrectomy.
results_summary: The study found that perioperative magnesium sulfate significantly reduced cumulative morphine consumption and pain scores compared to the control group, with no significant differences in sedation scores or demographics between groups.
population_specificity: Eighty obese patients undergoing sleeve gastrectomy at a university hospital.
study_duration: Perioperative (before, during, and 24 hours after surgery)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and benefits of opioid-free anesthesia as an alternative to traditional opioid-based approaches in bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study presents a multimodal opioid-free anesthesia protocol for bariatric surgery, highlighting its potential to circumvent opioid-related problems, though it also notes clinicians should be aware of potential issues with this approach.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a dissonance-based intervention on health-related quality of life (HRQoL), physical activity (PA), and other health behaviors in female RYGB patients 24 months after surgery.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, but it evaluates differences in HRQoL and health behaviors between an intervention group receiving a dissonance-based program and a control group receiving usual care, with follow-ups at 6 months, 1 year, and 2 years post-surgery.
population_specificity: Female RYGB patients in Sweden (n=259).
effective_dosage: Four group sessions three months post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the prevalence, diagnostic evaluations, etiology, and treatment of abdominal pain specific to Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery.
results_summary: Up to 30% of patients may experience recurrent abdominal pain long-term post-surgery, with heterogeneous causes including gallstone-related disease, intestinal obstruction, and dietary issues. Surgical treatment and dietary guidance may alleviate symptoms, but the cause remains undefined for some patients.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery (excluding early postoperative phase <30 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the current treatment options for pediatric severe obesity, including bariatric surgery, and suggest future opportunities for innovative strategies.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery provides robust weight loss and improvements in risk factors/comorbidities but carries higher risks and lower uptake compared to other treatments like lifestyle modification and pharmacotherapy. Long-term outcomes may benefit from post-surgical interventions.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with severe obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the methodological approaches, reporting quality, and findings of cost-effectiveness models for bariatric surgery in morbid obesity.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery is effective for long-term weight loss and remission of obesity-related co-morbidities, with laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass being the most cost-effective strategy. However, gaps in reporting and methodological quality were identified.
population_specificity: Adult patients with morbid obesity, aged 25-75 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of bariatric surgery in managing metabolic syndrome and prediabetes in individuals with a body mass index (BMI) of 30-35.
results_summary: The abstract suggests bariatric surgery can be offered to patients with metabolic syndrome and a BMI of 30-35, indicating its potential efficacy in managing metabolic conditions, though specific outcomes are not detailed.
population_specificity: Individuals with metabolic syndrome and a BMI of 30-35.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a boron nitride nanotube-enhanced membrane (PGBT) with ultrasound stimulation could improve osteogenesis and antibacterial properties for guided bone regeneration.
results_summary: The PGBT membrane demonstrated improved mechanical and biocompatible properties, generated piezovoltages under ultrasound, enhanced cellular osteogenesis, and showed a 40% antibacterial rate. In vivo rat cranial defect experiments confirmed its potential for vertical bone defect repair.
population_specificity: Rat model (cranial defects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role and mechanisms of boron (B) in alleviating antimony (Sb) toxicity in rice plants.
results_summary: Boron supplementation (30 μM) mitigated Sb toxicity by improving growth, photosynthesis, root activity, and oxidative balance, while reducing Sb concentration in roots and promoting its chelation onto cell walls.
population_specificity: Rice plants at the seedling stage grown in a hydroponic system.
study_duration: During the seedling stage (specific duration not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize and validate the i-TED Compton imager for real-time dosimetry in Boron Neutron Capture Therapy (BNCT).
results_summary: The study demonstrated the potential of i-TED detectors for accurate BNCT dosimetry through optimized Monte Carlo simulations and advanced 3D image reconstruction algorithms. Preliminary experimental tests at ILL showed promising results under simplified conditions, with ongoing work to validate performance in realistic BNCT environments.
population_specificity: Not specified (focused on detector optimization and simulation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop deep neural network models for faster and more accurate dose distribution estimation in boron neutron capture therapy (BNCT) to enable real-time dose monitoring during treatment.
results_summary: The study demonstrated that deep neural network models, particularly U-Net and its variants, significantly reduced reconstruction time (by a factor of ~6) compared to classical iterative algorithms while maintaining accuracy, making them suitable for real-time BNCT dose monitoring.
population_specificity: Not specified (simulated dataset used).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a case of acute kidney injury and ureteral injury potentially caused by boron crystals during boron neutron capture therapy (BNCT) for oropharyngeal cancer.
results_summary: The study found that BNCT led to acute kidney injury and ureteral injury in a patient, evidenced by macrohematuria, oliguria, and elevated creatinine levels. Discontinuation of BNCT and fluid supplementation resolved the symptoms, suggesting a potential risk of boron crystal-related injury during therapy.
population_specificity: A 77-year-old man with oropharyngeal cancer undergoing BNCT.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of exogenous boron (B) on salt tolerance in mangrove species, focusing on growth, morphology, physiology, and leaf anatomy under high salinity stress.
results_summary: Low-concentration boron (100 μM B) improved mangrove performance under high salinity, particularly in physiology and leaf anatomy, while high-concentration boron (500 μM B) had adverse effects. Species-specific responses to boron were observed in physiological and anatomical traits, linked to their inherent salt tolerance.
population_specificity: Three mangrove species (Avicennia marina, Aegiceras corniculatum, and Bruguiera gymnorrhiza) under simulated tidal conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify predictive biomarkers for therapeutic efficacy and side-effects of boron neutron capture therapy (BNCT) using 10B-boronophenylalanine (BPA) in oral cancer treatment.
results_summary: The study found increased expression of inflammatory and immune-related genes (CSF2, ATF3, MAFB, PTGS2, TNFAIP3) and activation of NF-κB pathway after BPA-BNCT. GM-CSF levels rose post-irradiation, suggesting its role in early responses to BNCT.
population_specificity: Human oral squamous carcinoma SAS cells (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: Therapeutic dose of BPA-BNCT at 24 Gy-eq.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the adsorption performance of porous hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) aerogels for tetracycline (TC) in water purification.
results_summary: The study found that porous h-BN aerogels (DP-BN) exhibited exceptional adsorption capacity for TC (1620.37 mg/g), rapid adsorption kinetics, and excellent reusability (99.93% removal rate after five cycles). The adsorption process was dominated by chemisorption and was exothermic, with increased capacity at higher temperatures.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on water purification, not human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (adsorption capacity measured in mg/g, not a dosage for consumption).
study_duration: Not applicable (study focused on adsorption kinetics and cycles, not a timed intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to verify the accuracy and efficiency of the partial-MC-RD calculation method for dose calculation in boron neutron capture therapy (BNCT).
results_summary: The partial-MC-RD calculation method showed comparable accuracy to the full-MC method while reducing calculation time by approximately 45% for specific head phantom regions. Discrepancies were attributed to assumptions in the RD calculation.
population_specificity: Head phantom comprising soft tissue, brain tissue, and bone (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a catalytic asymmetric synthesis method for chiral 3-amino-BODIPYs and explore their photophysical properties.
results_summary: The study successfully synthesized boron-stereogenic 3-amino-BODIPYs via palladium-catalyzed desymmetric C-N cross-coupling, achieving broad substrate scope, high efficiency, and excellent enantioselectivity. The method also enabled stereospecific formation of chiral 3,5-diamino-BODIPYs and investigated their photophysical properties.
population_specificity: Not applicable (chemical synthesis study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of AB-Lac nanoparticles loaded with boron compounds for targeted cancer therapy and dual diagnostic-therapeutic ("theranostic") applications.
results_summary: AB-Lac particles loaded with boron compounds (10B-Carb or 10B-diC6-Carb) significantly inhibited pancreatic cancer cell growth, with 10B-diC6-Carb showing superior efficacy. Surprisingly, ICG-labeled AB-Lac particles alone also exhibited significant inhibitory effects.
population_specificity: Human pancreatic cancer (AsPC-1) cells in vitro and in vivo.
study_duration: Maximum accumulation observed by 12 hours post-injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current knowledge of boron neutron capture therapy (BNCT), focusing on its radiobiology, DNA damage and repair mechanisms, and the development of new boron-containing compounds to enhance treatment specificity and effectiveness.
results_summary: BNCT shows promise for treating recurring and highly invasive tumors by creating densely ionizing particles within cancer cells, sparing normal tissues, and achieving more effective tumor control than X-rays. However, challenges include limited neutron sources and the need for better boron accumulation strategies in cancer cells, with BPA being the primary compound used.
population_specificity: Patients with recurring and highly invasive tumors (human cancers).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze trends, hotspots, and future directions in boron neutron capture therapy (BNCT) through a bibliometric review of published literature.
results_summary: The study found that BNCT research has expanded significantly over three decades, with Japan and the USA leading in publications and citations. Key areas of focus included novel boron carriers, brain tumors, and accelerator-based neutron sources.
population_specificity: Not specified (bibliometric analysis of published literature).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficiency of boron removal from effluents using electrosorption technology with nanodiamond anodes and develop a predictive model for system optimization.
results_summary: The study demonstrated enhanced boron adsorption capacity (10.5 μmol/g) with low energy consumption (<3.4 kWh g-B) using nanodiamond anodes, and successfully applied machine learning to predict effluent properties, identifying voltage as a key predictive factor.
population_specificity: Effluents (water treatment context)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of using a boronophenylalanine-driven beam shaping assembly (BSA) for targeted neutron therapy, assessing its performance and dose delivery in a phantom model.
results_summary: The study found that the high-performance BSA achieved therapeutic and advantage depths of 5.1 cm and 8.3 cm, respectively, with an irradiation time of 3421 s. Experimental validation confirmed that simulation calculations accurately predicted neutron dose distribution, supporting the BSA's potential for deep-seated lesion treatment.
population_specificity: Phantom model (no human or animal subjects mentioned).
effective_dosage: Not specified (boronophenylalanine carrier used, but exact dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Irradiation time was 3421 s (~57 minutes) for the high-performance BSA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a novel boron agent (BBC-IP) for boron neutron capture therapy (BNCT) with improved tumor accumulation and efficacy compared to the approved drug BPA.
results_summary: BBC-IP showed high water solubility, minimal cytotoxicity, and superior cellular uptake compared to BPA, achieving enhanced tumor accumulation in mouse colon tumors. However, BPA demonstrated superior BNCT efficacy, likely due to differences in intracellular localization.
population_specificity: Human and mouse cancer cells (colon tumors in mice).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a novel anticoincidence detector to improve the measurement of 478 keV gamma radiation for evaluating boron neutron capture therapy.
results_summary: The proposed detector effectively suppressed the Compton continuum around the target photopeak by measuring only Compton gamma rays scattered at small angles, achieving an 80% reduction in counts in simulations and 4% suppression in prototype testing with cobalt-60 gamma rays.
population_specificity: Not specified (focused on detector technology, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare radionuclide drug conjugates (RDC) with boron neutron capture therapy (BNCT) to highlight recent developments in targeted alpha-particle therapy for treating malignant tumors.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that targeted alpha-particle therapy, including BNCT, shows promise in improving tumor treatment efficacy while minimizing side effects, supported by academic research and clinical trials.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on tumor cells and clinical applications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the design and performance of a compact accelerator-driven neutron source for Boron Neutron Capture Therapy (BNCT), focusing on thermal and epithermal neutron ports.
results_summary: The study demonstrated that the neutron ports complied with IAEA recommendations, with thermal neutron flux peaking at the skin for the thermal port and at a depth of 3 cm in the head phantom for the epithermal port. The photon-isoeffective dose showed 35%-15% lower values than the photon equivalent dose in the treatment region.
population_specificity: Not specified (in-phantom study using a modified Snyder head phantom).
effective_dosage: Not specified (proton beam parameters: 10 mA, 2.5 MeV).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of shielding strategies on neutron capture detection accuracy in Boron-based applications for Neutron Capture Enhanced Particle Therapy (NCEPT).
results_summary: Shielding the detector crystal decreased true/false positive detection ratios by over 50% and increased activation, but shielding electronics with boron-containing PCBs using Gd2O3 improved detection selectivity by up to 21%.
population_specificity: Simulated irradiation of a poly(methyl methacrylate) phantom and cubic 10B insert.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the formation and properties of a novel dynamic covalent polymer (P(ID-O-B)) derived from the coordination of 5,5',6,6'-tetrahydroxyindigo and boron tribromide.
results_summary: The study found that the polymer P(ID-O-B) exhibits a triplet ground state and a thermally populated doublet state, confirmed by EPR, and demonstrates electrical conductivity over 10-6 S cm-1 despite being non-conjugated. The polymer is stable under long-term storage and thermal treatment up to 200 °C but can be depolymerized with methanol.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate boronated tryptophans as potential boron delivery agents for boron neutron capture therapy (BNCT) in cancer treatment, comparing their uptake to l-BPA in cancer cell lines.
results_summary: The study found differences in boron compound accumulation between CAL27 (head and neck cancer) and U87-MG (brain cancer) cell lines, suggesting tryptophan derivatives could be effective boron carriers when BPA is ineffective. Molecular dynamics simulations explored their transport mechanism via large amino acid transporter 1.
population_specificity: Human cancer cell lines (CAL27 and U87-MG).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of three extended collimator designs in reducing radiation dose to normal tissues and protecting organs at risk during Boron Neutron Capture Therapy (BNCT).
results_summary: Type 2 collimator reduced neutron leakage dose by up to 57.14%, while Type 3 reduced gamma-ray leakage dose by up to 21.88%. Both designs showed significant reductions in organ-specific doses, with Type 2 particularly effective for skin, thyroid, spinal cord, and left lung, and Type 3 beneficial for thyroid, esophagus, and left lung.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing BNCT (simulated via humanoid phantom model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a durable, reusable, and efficient boron-removal system using a multiscale porous anion-exchangeable sponge (MP-AES) for water treatment.
results_summary: The MP-AES demonstrated high boron-adsorption efficiency (21 mg/g in 20 min), outperforming commercial resin by 120% in low-solute conditions, and maintained performance over 10 regeneration cycles and 100 compression cycles without structural failure. It also met stringent drinking water standards (0.5-1 mg/L).
population_specificity: Water treatment applications (no human or animal subjects specified).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (adsorption system tested with 100 mg/L and 2 mg/L boron solutions).
study_duration: Testing included 20-minute adsorption periods and 10 regeneration cycles.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic effect of Boron Neutron Capture Therapy (BNCT) on myxofibrosarcoma using a tumor-bearing animal model.
results_summary: The study demonstrated selective destruction of tumor cells, suggesting BNCT has anti-tumor efficacy against myxofibrosarcoma.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with myxofibrosarcoma in the upper limbs (cell lines derived from amputated surgical specimens).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a B2O3 coating could improve the crystallinity, orientation, and defect properties of Sb2Se3 thin films for enhanced photovoltaic performance.
results_summary: The study found that B2O3 treatment induced vertical orientation growth in Sb2Se3 films, reduced Se vacancy defects, and improved charge carrier transport, resulting in a record 9.37% solar cell efficiency.
population_specificity: Inorganic thin films (Sb2Se3 photovoltaic materials)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanism of silver-silicon (Ag-Si) contact formation on the P+ emitter of TOPCon solar cells via laser-enhanced contact optimization (LECO) and compare the performance of two types of glass frits (GF-A and GF-B).
results_summary: The study found that GF-A-based TOPCon cells outperformed GF-B-based cells due to the construction of a current-confined Ag-Si interface. A composite conductive model for Ag-Si interfaces by LECO treatment was introduced, revealing nano-size Joule-heating as the mechanism for achieving the Ag-Si eutectic structure.
population_specificity: Not applicable (study focused on solar cell technology, not human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of boron-doped porous biochar in adsorbing contaminants like tetracycline, phenolics, and dyes.
results_summary: The boron-doped porous biochar demonstrated high adsorption capacity (413.223 mg/g for tetracycline), outperforming unmodified biochar and commercial adsorbents, with enhanced π-π electron donor-acceptor interactions due to -BCO2 groups. It also showed broad applicability for removing various pollutants and maintained stability with regenerable adsorption capacity.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on biochar material).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether boron nitride quantum dots (BNQDs) could enhance the activation of peracetic acid (PAA) for antibiotic degradation in wastewater treatment.
results_summary: The study found that BNQDs-modified Fe-doped g-C3N4 catalyst significantly improved the reaction rate constant (0.0843 min-1) for PAA activation, demonstrating selective degradation of oxygen-containing functional groups in antibiotics.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on wastewater treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of boron-doped nano hydroxyapatite grafts on craniofacial bone regeneration in critical bone defects in rats.
results_summary: The study found that boron-doped nano hydroxyapatite (2% boron) showed statistically significant improvement in bone healing compared to untreated defects, though no significant difference was observed between 1% boron and untreated groups. The 2% boron group had the closest histopathological scores to the healthy control group.
population_specificity: Male Wistar albino rats (16-18 weeks old, 200-220 g).
