effective_dosage: 1% and 2% boron combined with nano hydroxyapatite, applied once to the surgical defect.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a boron nanosensitizer (BATBN) that improves tumor-specific accumulation and retention of boron-10 for more effective boron neutron capture therapy (BNCT).
results_summary: BATBN demonstrated a 2.4-fold increase in intratumoral boron concentration and a 5.0-fold increase in tumor retention time compared to boron quantum dots (BQDs), leading to a 2.7-fold reduction in tumor volume after neutron irradiation.
population_specificity: Preclinical tumor models (not specified if human or animal).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a novel automated robotic-assisted patient positioning system for improving the accuracy and efficacy of Boron Neutron Capture Therapy (BNCT) in cancer treatment.
results_summary: The study found that the robotic positioning system achieved high accuracy, with deviations of ≤3 mm in Source-to-Skin Distance (SSD) and ≤2 mm along the surface, resulting in dose changes of <1% (surface) and <5% (SSD). The system significantly enhanced BNCT treatment delivery precision.
population_specificity: Anthropomorphic phantom (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the applicability of boron-based neutron filters in achieving sensitivity to epithermal neutron energy for applications like Boron Neutron Capture Therapy (BNCT) and new reactor technologies.
results_summary: The study demonstrated that boron-based neutron filters, in conjunction with specific nuclear reactions, can effectively achieve sensitivity in the epithermal energy range, which is crucial for BNCT and advanced reactor designs. Future research avenues were also discussed to further explore this context.
population_specificity: Not specified (focused on neutron activation dosimetry and reactor/BNCT applications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of varying boron concentrations in hydroxyapatite-chitosan nano-composites on the microhardness of demineralized enamel.
results_summary: The study found that boron-doped nano-composites (5%, 10%, and 15% boron) significantly improved enamel microhardness compared to the control, with the 15% boron group showing the highest microhardness. However, no significant differences were observed between the boron concentration groups (5%, 10%, and 15%).
population_specificity: Intact human premolars (30 teeth, divided into buccal and lingual halves).
effective_dosage: Boron concentrations of 5%, 10%, and 15% in hydroxyapatite-chitosan nano-composites.
study_duration: 14 days of pH cycling for demineralization, followed by remineralization treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a biodegradable boron nanoreactor (TBNR) for enhanced tumor accumulation and retention in boron neutron capture therapy (BNCT) and chemodynamic therapy (CDT).
results_summary: The TBNR demonstrated superior tumor accumulation, triggered CDT, and induced immune responses, leading to significant tumor shrinkage and long-term suppression post neutron irradiation.
population_specificity: Subcutaneous 4T1 tumors in vivo (animal model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of boron citrate supplementation on cardiometabolic factors, inflammatory biomarkers, anthropometric measures, and body composition in obese patients.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, as the study is yet to be conducted. The findings will assess the effectiveness of boron citrate in obesity management.
population_specificity: Obese participants aged 18-60 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential therapeutic role of boron in modulating the gut microbiome and alleviating neuropathic pain in complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS).
results_summary: The study suggests boron supplementation may positively modulate the gut microbiome, reduce inflammation, and alleviate neuropathic pain in CRPS, based on preclinical and clinical evidence.
population_specificity: Individuals with complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a method using boron-based materials (BA-CDs and COF@VBC@BA-CDs) for rapid detection and analysis of amatoxins in mushrooms and urine samples.
results_summary: The study demonstrated that BA-CDs and COF@VBC@BA-CDs effectively detected amatoxins via fluorescence quenching and LC-MS/MS, with detection limits of 1.2 μg/L (fluorescence) and 0.5 μg/kg (mushrooms) or 0.2 μg/L (urine), and recovery rates of 72.7-110.1%.
population_specificity: Mushroom and urine samples (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of boron supplement (due to its anti-inflammatory effect) and tamsulosin in facilitating stone fragment passage after ESWL.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant difference in stone expulsion rates between boron (46.6%) and tamsulosin (38.7%) groups, nor in stone clearance time or pain intensity. Boron was deemed effective as adjuvant therapy with no significant side effects.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent ESWL for stone fragmentation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate dietary strategies, including boron supplementation, to reduce bone mineral density loss in osteopenia/osteoporosis patients.
results_summary: The study suggested boron supplementation could be an effective strategy for meeting daily nutritional requirements when diet alone is insufficient, with a favorable benefit/cost ratio.
population_specificity: Osteopenia/osteoporosis patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the role of minerals and trace elements, including Boron, in exercise and athletic performance.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings regarding Boron's effects, as it focuses on the broader review of minerals and trace elements.
population_specificity: Athletes and individuals engaged in exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular composition and formation mechanism of chlorinated dissolved organic matter (DOM) during electrochemical oxidation using a boron-doped diamond (BDD) anode in biologically treated leachate.
results_summary: The study found that electrochemical oxidation with a BDD anode effectively removed DOM but also generated 479 unknown chlorinated DOM species (21.55% of total) and 43.63 mg/L of known chlorinated species (e.g., dichloroacetic and trichloroacetic acids). Reactive chlorine species formed during the process contributed to chlorinated DOM generation via specific reaction pathways.
population_specificity: Biologically treated waste leachate

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of boron supplementation (alone or with other nutrients) on bone health by examining its role in calcium, vitamin D, and sex steroid hormone metabolism, and to suggest a daily dosage.
results_summary: The review found that a dietary supplementation of 3 mg/day of boron (alone or with other nutrients) positively affects bone health by supporting calcium, vitamin D, and sex steroid hormone metabolism, and is useful for maintaining bone mineral density. The dosage is well below the EFSA's Upper Level of 10 mg/day.
population_specificity: Humans (general population, focus on bone health)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the pleiotropic effects of boron, including its role in immune response, bone metabolism, antioxidant activity, and overall animal health, while also assessing the risks of deficiency or excess.
results_summary: Boron plays a vital role in maintaining animal health, enhancing immune function, bone density, wound healing, and embryonic development, but excessive levels can cause toxicity and cell damage. The study also highlights boron's potential as an anti-heat stress agent and its impact on liver metabolism in dairy cows.
population_specificity: Animals (including dairy cows) and implied relevance to humans.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, biochemical characteristics, and clinical outcomes of calcium fructoborate (CaFB), a sugar-borate ester, as a dietary supplement for joint discomfort management.
results_summary: The study found that CaFB significantly reduced knee discomfort and improved flexibility within 7, 14, and 90 days, with positive effects on inflammatory and cardiovascular biomarkers. These results support its use as a dietary supplement for joint health.
population_specificity: Human subjects, likely adults with joint discomfort (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the role of Boron as an essential trace element in the physiological functioning of higher plants and its impact on metabolism and growth.
results_summary: The study found that Boron is crucial for the structural and functional integrity of plant cell walls and membranes, and its deficiency adversely affects plant metabolism and growth. It also plays a role in ion fluxes (H⁺, K⁺, PO₄).
population_specificity: Higher plants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the biological roles and health effects of boron, including its benefits and risks at different intake levels.
results_summary: Boron shows pleiotropic effects, including anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and immune-enhancing properties, with benefits for bone density, cognitive function, and hepatic metabolism. However, both low and high boron status are associated with health risks, indicating a need for balanced intake.
population_specificity: Animals and humans

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Boron supplementation could reduce the severity and duration of menstrual pain in female university students with primary dysmenorrhea.
results_summary: Boron supplementation significantly reduced both the severity and duration of menstrual pain compared to placebo, with statistically significant results (P < 0.05). The study suggests Boron's anti-inflammatory effects may contribute to these improvements.
population_specificity: Female university students with primary dysmenorrhea.
effective_dosage: 10 mg/day, taken from two days before menstruation until the third day of menstrual flow.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effect of boron and other trace elements on bone health and evaluate their clinical importance.
results_summary: The study suggests that boron, along with other trace elements, positively influences bone health, and deficiency of these elements can slow bone mass increase in childhood/adolescence and accelerate bone loss in menopause/old age. Monitoring homeostasis of trace elements is recommended to identify and treat at-risk patients.
population_specificity: General population, with specific mentions of childhood, adolescence, menopause, and old age.

study_goal: The researchers compared the pharmacokinetics of genistein in different formulations, including an OTC supplement containing boron, to assess absorption and bioavailability.
results_summary: The study did not report specific findings on boron's effects, focusing instead on genistein's pharmacokinetics. The OTC supplement's synthetic genistein showed altered absorption, possibly due to interference from multiple ingredients, including boron.
population_specificity: Healthy postmenopausal women (n = 30)
effective_dosage: 250 μg boron per two tablets (OTC supplement)
interactions: Multiple ingredients in the OTC supplement may interfere with genistein absorption.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether acute and weekly boron supplementation could significantly affect steroid hormones and inflammatory biomarkers in healthy males.
results_summary: Boron supplementation significantly increased plasma boron levels, reduced SHBG, hsCRP, and TNF-α levels, increased free testosterone and dihydrotestosterone, decreased estradiol, and lowered inflammatory biomarkers after one week.
population_specificity: Eight healthy male volunteers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory properties and safety of calcium fructoborate, a boron-based supplement, in vitro and in vivo.
results_summary: Calcium fructoborate demonstrated anti-inflammatory effects by scavenging superoxide ions, inhibiting inflammatory mediators (IL-1β, IL-6, nitric oxide), and increasing TNF-α production. Animal and human studies showed good anti-inflammatory activity with negligible adverse effects at doses of 1-7 mg/kg/day.
population_specificity: Animals and humans (specific demographics not detailed).
effective_dosage: 1-7 mg calcium fructoborate (0.025-0.175 mg elemental boron)/kg body weight/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of Boswellia serrata in combination with Therabite® for treating severe post-radiation trismus.
results_summary: The study found that Boswellia serrata combined with Therabite® led to a dramatic improvement in jaw opening (from 6 mm to 45 mm over 10 weeks) with no reported adverse effects. The improvement rate exceeded previously documented rates for other treatments.
population_specificity: A 54-year-old male with severe post-radiation trismus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antimicrobial effects of Boswellia serrata extract on oral pathogens associated with periodontitis, specifically Porphyromonas gingivalis and Fusobacterium nucleatum.
results_summary: B. serrata extract impaired P. gingivalis growth and biofilm formation but had no significant effect on F. nucleatum. Non-toxic concentrations of the extract also reduced intracellular P. gingivalis infection in human gingival epithelial cells.
population_specificity: Human gingival epithelial cells and oral pathogens (P. gingivalis and F. nucleatum).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic efficacy of standardized Boswellia serrata gum resin extract (BSRE) in a rat model of osteoarthritis induced by monosodium iodoacetate (MIA).
results_summary: BSRE significantly reduced knee joint swelling, cartilage destruction, and tissue deformation, while upregulating COL2A1 and aggrecan expression and reducing inflammatory mediators and cytokines. The highest dose (100 mg/kg BW) showed the most notable improvements.
population_specificity: Rats with MIA-induced osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: 50 mg/kg, 75 mg/kg, and 100 mg/kg body weight.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Boswellia serrata (BS) extract in managing osteoarthritis (OA) symptoms and compare the effectiveness of a standardized BS extract (AflapinⓇ) with other BS extracts.
results_summary: BS supplementation significantly reduced pain, inflammation, and functional disability in OA patients, with AflapinⓇ showing greater improvements in symptom relief compared to other BS therapies.
population_specificity: 712 participants with osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Boswellia Sacra Gum Resin (BSR) could modulate neuronal autophagy and protein expression post-TBI and improve functional recovery in a mouse model of TBI.
results_summary: BSR treatment limited histological alterations, lipid peroxidation, antioxidant depletion, cytokine release, and autophagic flux disruption induced by TBI, suggesting neuroprotective effects.
population_specificity: Mouse model of traumatic brain injury (TBI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Boswellia papyrifera, alone or in combination with Syzygium aromaticum, could mitigate cognitive dysfunction and oxidative stress in an aluminum chloride-induced Alzheimer's disease rat model.
results_summary: Boswellia papyrifera significantly improved cognitive function, increased acetylcholinesterase levels, enhanced oxidative enzymes (SOD and GSH), and reduced MDA levels in brain homogenates, with combination therapy yielding better results than single treatment. Histopathological improvements were also observed.
population_specificity: Rats with aluminum chloride-induced Alzheimer's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the acaricidal and antifungal efficacy of Boswellia carterii resin extracts against Tetranychus urticae and fungal pathogens.
results_summary: The ethyl-acetate extract (FEAE) showed potent antifungal activity, completely inhibiting mycelial growth at 4000 ppm, while the petroleum-ether extract (FPEE) was more toxic to T. urticae, with an LC50 of 422.52 ppm. Both extracts exhibited notable antioxidant activity.
population_specificity: Adult females of Tetranychus urticae and five fungal pathogens.
effective_dosage: 10 mg/ml for antioxidant activity; 4000 ppm for antifungal efficacy; LC50 values of 422.52 ppm (FPEE) and 539.50 ppm (FEAE) for acaricidal activity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Boswellia serrata pretreatment on LPS-induced cardiac damage in H9c2 cells, focusing on its anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties.
results_summary: Boswellia serrata pretreatment reduced inflammatory markers (TNF-α, PGE2, IL-1β, COX-2, iNOS, IL-6, NO) and increased cell viability and GSH levels in LPS-treated H9c2 cells, suggesting protective effects against cardiac injury.
population_specificity: H9c2 cells (a rat cardiomyocyte cell line)
study_duration: 24 hours pretreatment, followed by 24 hours LPS stimulation

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a turmeric-boswellia-sesame formulation in relieving menstrual pain compared to a placebo in women with primary dysmenorrhea.
results_summary: The turmeric-boswellia-sesame formulation showed significantly better pain relief compared to placebo, with 12.6 times higher mean total pain relief (TOTPAR) and 20.19 times better sum of pain intensity difference at 6 hours (SPID6). Pain intensity reduction was statistically significant at every measured timepoint.
population_specificity: Sixty women with primary dysmenorrhea.
effective_dosage: 1000 mg (two 500 mg softgels) as a single dose when pain reached ≥5 on the NRS.
study_duration: Single-dose intervention with pain monitoring for 6 hours post-dose.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of dietary frankincense resin oil (FO) on growth performance, immune status, intestinal health, and fatty acid composition in broiler chickens.
results_summary: FO supplementation improved body weight, feed conversion ratio, immune markers (Complement 3, lysozyme, interleukin 10), and fatty acid profiles (n-3 and n-6) in broilers, while also enhancing intestinal morphology.
population_specificity: Male Ross 308 broiler chicks (three-day-old).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Boswellia serrata extract (BSE) could reduce osteoarthritis (OA) symptoms and slow its progression through anti-nociceptive and anti-inflammatory properties.
results_summary: Oral administration of BSE significantly improved locomotor activity, pain thresholds, and reduced inflammatory markers (IL-1β, IL-6, TNF-α) in OA-induced mice, demonstrating anti-nociceptive and anti-inflammatory effects. The study also found BSE to be practically nontoxic with a high safety profile.
population_specificity: NMRI mice with monosodium iodoacetate (MIA)-induced osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: 100 and 200 mg/kg of BSE, administered orally daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the burn wound healing effects of a Boswellia carteri topical formulation with the standard silver sulfadiazine (SSD) 1% cream.
results_summary: The Boswellia formulation showed comparable healing effects to SSD, with no significant difference in healing time (10.73 vs. 10.94 days). By day 17, all Boswellia-treated patients achieved complete healing, but the study noted a potential risk of contact dermatitis.
population_specificity: 54 second-degree burn patients aged 20-60, of both sexes.
effective_dosage: 40% Boswellia carteri formulation (specific frequency not mentioned).
study_duration: Up to 17 days (until complete healing in Boswellia group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of 5-Loxin (Boswellia serrata) in treating symptomatic adverse radiation effects (AREs) after stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS).
results_summary: The study found that 5-Loxin resolved neurological symptoms and imaging changes in all three patients, allowed discontinuation of steroids, and had no reported side effects. The authors suggest it may be a promising first-line treatment for AREs.
population_specificity: Patients who developed symptomatic AREs (perilesional edema) after SRS for meningioma or metastasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects of Boswellia gum resin extract in an experimental autoimmune myocarditis (EAM) model and investigate its molecular pathways.
results_summary: Boswellia extract significantly reduced myocardial damage, inflammatory infiltrate, fibrosis, biochemical markers (e.g., lactate dehydrogenase, creatine kinase), and oxidative stress while upregulating the NRF-2 antioxidant pathway in EAM rats.
population_specificity: Rats with experimentally induced autoimmune myocarditis.

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of a Boswellia and ginger mixture on memory dysfunction in patients with mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI).
results_summary: The herbal mixture (Memoral) significantly improved certain memory parameters (total learning, retroactive interference score, forgetting rate, and net positive score) compared to placebo at one and three months, while other parameters (word span and hit) improved similarly in both groups. The treatment showed no considerable adverse effects and sustained benefits after two months.
population_specificity: Patients with mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI), mean age 36.83±14.71.
effective_dosage: 360 mg Boswellia and 36 mg ginger daily.
study_duration: 1 month of intervention, with follow-ups at 1 and 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether a food supplement containing Boswellia serrata and Curcuma longa could relieve hand pain in patients with osteoarthritis when added to standard care.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in pain intensity and the number of painful joints, along with decreased NSAID use and high patient satisfaction. Only 1.3% of patients reported side effects likely related to the supplement.
population_specificity: 232 patients with hand pain due to osteoarthritis, with or without joint deformity.
effective_dosage: 120 mg Boswellia serrata resin daily (combined with 89 mg Curcuma longa dry extract and 1.8 µg vitamin D).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the therapeutic potential and mechanism of 5-Loxin®, a standardized Boswellia serrata extract, in a rat model of osteoarthritis (OA).
results_summary: 5-Loxin® relieved OA joint pain by inhibiting inflammatory processes and cartilage degeneration, reducing inflammatory enzymes (COX-2, 5-LOX) and ECM deterioration (GAGs, aggrecan) via MMP downregulation.
population_specificity: Rat model of OA induced by monosodium iodoacetate (MIA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the antibacterial effect and phagocytic ability of the aqueous extract of Boswellia carterii against bacteria isolated from nosocomial infections.
results_summary: The aqueous extract of Boswellia carterii demonstrated antibacterial activity against all tested bacterial isolates, with higher concentrations yielding larger inhibition zones. It also significantly increased the phagocytosis rate in treated blood samples compared to controls.
population_specificity: Patients of both genders and different age groups with nosocomial infections (urine, sputum, wounds, otitis, and blood samples).
effective_dosage: 25 mg/ml and 200 mg/ml concentrations of the extract were tested.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the analgesic effect of a turmeric and boswellia extract formulation (TBF) in reducing exercise-induced acute musculoskeletal pain.
results_summary: TBF significantly reduced pain intensity, with 97.85% improvement in cumulative responder analysis compared to 2.46% in placebo. Fast onset of pain relief was observed, with 99% of participants experiencing perceptible relief at 68.5 minutes and 96% achieving meaningful relief at 191.6 minutes.
population_specificity: Healthy participants with moderate-to-severe exercise-induced acute musculoskeletal pain.
study_duration: Single-day intervention with follow-up up to 6 hours post-dose.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of dietary supplementation with Boswellia serrata and Salix alba extracts on serum and albumen proteins, trace elements, and yolk cholesterol in Leghorn hens during the onset of laying.
results_summary: No significant differences were observed between control and supplemented hens for the analyzed biochemical indices. The supplementation did not negatively affect physiological variations in serum proteins, suggesting it can be safely used to prevent inflammatory states during the early laying phase.
population_specificity: Leghorn hens (17 weeks old, n=120)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanisms of action of Boswellia serrata (BS) extracts at therapeutic plasmatic concentrations on primary human osteoarthritic chondrocytes, focusing on anti-oxidative, anti-inflammatory, and anti-catabolic effects.
results_summary: BS exhibited significant anti-inflammatory and anti-catabolic effects, down-regulating pro-inflammatory cytokines, Toll-like receptors (TLRs), and genes like ADAMTS1, 5, and MMP3, 13. Its effects were distinct from Curcuma longa (CL), activating Nrf1 and PPARα pathways, and were more effective when combined with CL.
population_specificity: Primary chondrocytes isolated from 17 osteoarthritis (OA) patients, with RNA-sequencing analysis performed on 10 patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the penetration depth and effectiveness of Boswellia sacra as an intracanal medicament against Enterococcus faecalis biofilm compared to calcium hydroxide.
results_summary: Boswellia sacra showed greater effectiveness than calcium hydroxide at 3 days, though the difference was statistically insignificant after 7 days. It also demonstrated superior penetration depth compared to calcium hydroxide.
population_specificity: Single-rooted teeth contaminated with Enterococcus faecalis biofilm.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the antiviral properties of Boswellia species and their potential therapeutic effects, particularly in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic.
results_summary: The study highlighted Boswellia's broad pharmacological activities, including antiviral effects, especially from its oleo-gum-resin, suggesting potential benefits for viral infections like COVID-19. However, specific clinical outcomes or detailed efficacy data were not provided.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of pharmacological studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of Boswellia serrata (Kundur) to Miconazole nitrate in treating vulvovaginal candidiasis (VVC).
results_summary: Boswellia was more effective than Miconazole in reducing vulval itching and vaginal discharge but equally effective in improving other symptoms and quality of life. Both treatments significantly improved VVC symptoms.
population_specificity: 40 married women aged 18-45 diagnosed with VVC.
effective_dosage: 1-gram tablet of Kundur as a vaginal insert daily at bedtime.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of oral Boswellia serrata (combined with Curcuma longa) on maintaining central macular thickness and visual acuity in patients with non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy and treatment-naïve diabetic macular edema.
results_summary: The study found that oral administration of Boswellia serrata and Curcuma longa (Retimix®) significantly maintained baseline central macular thickness and best-corrected visual acuity over six months compared to observation alone, with statistically significant interaction effects.
population_specificity: Patients with non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy and treatment-naïve diabetic macular edema (<400 μm).
effective_dosage: One sachet per day (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Aflapin, a bioavailable Boswellia serrata extract, in managing osteoarthritis symptoms.
results_summary: Aflapin significantly improved pain and physical function scores within five days, reduced inflammatory biomarkers, and showed no significant adverse effects.
population_specificity: 70 subjects with knee osteoarthritis, per American College of Rheumatology criteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a lecithin-based delivery form of Boswellia serrata (CASP) is effective and safe for treating acute diarrhea in adults.
results_summary: The study found that CASP significantly reduced the duration of diarrhea, stool frequency, abdominal pain, and nausea compared to placebo, with a recovery probability of 80.2%. The intervention group recovered 1.36 days faster on average.
population_specificity: 49 adults with acute diarrhea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the mechanism by which Boswellia serrata extract inhibits pro-inflammatory cytokines in zebrafish larvae with LPS-induced inflammation and evaluate its antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects.
results_summary: The study found that Boswellia serrata extract at 80 µg/mL significantly reduced intracellular ROS, apoptosis, lipid peroxidation, nitric oxide, and inflammatory gene expression (iNOS, TNF-α, COX-2, and IL-1) in zebrafish larvae, demonstrating potent anti-inflammatory and antioxidant activity. Higher concentrations (160 µg/mL) were toxic, while lower concentrations (10-80 µg/mL) were protective.
population_specificity: Zebrafish (Danio rerio) larvae

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of rectal Boswellia resin extract and propolis polyphenols in treating chronic prostatitis and chronic pelvic pain syndrome (CP/CPPS).
results_summary: The treatment significantly improved NIH-CPSI total scores, pain, micturition, and quality of life domains, as well as IPSS scores, with no adverse events reported. Further improvements were observed at the 90-day follow-up, though no significant changes in erectile function or maximum flow rate were noted.
population_specificity: 61 males with type IIIa and type IIIb CP/CPPS.
effective_dosage: One rectal suppository daily for 15 days per month.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether K-Vie™ (Boswellia) improves cognitive function in patients with a history of traumatic brain injury (TBI).
results_summary: The study found significant improvement in cognitive function (p < 0.05) in the K-Vie™ group compared to placebo across multiple cognitive assessments (RAVLT, DSST, TMT-B). A larger cohort was suggested to further confirm clinical utility.
population_specificity: Patients who suffered TBI 3 months to 3 years prior to the study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically summarize studies on the bioactivities of Boswellia compounds and extracts, focusing on pharmacological properties and phytochemicals of B. carterii.
results_summary: Boswellia extracts and compounds demonstrated anti-inflammatory, antitumour, and antioxidant activities, with positive effects on ageing-related diseases like diabetes, cancer, cardiovascular disease, and neurodegenerative diseases. The study proposes further evidence-based research on plant-derived remedies.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review, no specific population studied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of curcumin and boswellia extracts (as Curcumin Boswellia Phytosome, CBP) combined with a Low FODMAP diet (LFD) in reducing abdominal bloating in IBS subjects with small bowel dysbiosis, compared to LFD alone.
results_summary: The intervention group (CBP + LFD) showed a significant decrease in bloating, abdominal pain, and indican values compared to the control group (LFD alone), with a highly significant improvement in global assessment of efficacy (p < 0.0001).
population_specificity: Subjects with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) and small bowel dysbiosis (defined by increased urinary indican with normal urinary skatole).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify bioactive compounds from Boswellia serrata that could inhibit SARS-CoV-2 by targeting its main protease (Mpro) through computational methods.
results_summary: Five compounds from Boswellia serrata (Euphane, Ursane, α-Amyrin, Phytosterols, and 2,3-Dihydroxyurs-12-en-28-oic acid) showed potential to inhibit Mpro activity, with Euphane exhibiting the highest binding affinity across multiple SARS-CoV-2 targets. Further in-vitro validation is needed.
population_specificity: Computational study (no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current evidence on the potential therapeutic effects of boswellic acids/B. serrata extract in type 2 diabetes (T2D) and Alzheimer's disease (AD).
results_summary: Preclinical and small human clinical studies suggest that boswellic acids/B. serrata extract may have therapeutic effects in T2D and AD, attributed to anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and immunomodulatory properties. However, more large-scale randomized controlled trials are needed for definitive conclusions.
population_specificity: Preclinical studies and small human clinical trials (specific population not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory and anti-arthritic mechanisms of Boswellin Super® FJ (BSE) in vitro and in a rat model of collagen-induced arthritis.
results_summary: BSE significantly inhibited inflammatory markers (TNF-α, IL-6, COX-2) and reduced arthritic symptoms in rats, comparable to celecoxib. It also preserved extracellular matrix proteins and reduced oxidative stress.
population_specificity: RAW 264.7 macrophages, human peripheral blood mononuclear cells, and rats with collagen-induced arthritis.
effective_dosage: In vitro: 1.25-5μg/ml; in vivo: 40 and 80mg/kg orally.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the cell death induction effect of Boswellia dalzielii stem bark chloroform extract in head and neck cancer cells (AW8507) and its impact on cell cycle and apoptosis proteins.
results_summary: The study found that Boswellia dalzielii chloroform extract increased early apoptosis in AW8507 cells and identified acetyl-11-keto-beta-boswellic acid as a multi-protein target compound that obstructs cell cycle progression and binds tightly to αβ tubulin.
population_specificity: Head and neck cancer cell line (AW8507)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antibacterial and antibiofilm activity of Boswellia sacra (frankincense) extract against Porphyromonas gingivalis, a periodontal pathogen.
results_summary: The frankincense extract demonstrated antibacterial and antibiofilm effects, reducing bacterial growth, nucleotide leakage, extracellular polysaccharide production, and biofilm formation while downregulating biofilm-related genes.
population_specificity: Porphyromonas gingivalis clinical isolates (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antibacterial activity of Boswellia sacra extracts against gastrointestinal pathogens and bacterial triggers of autoimmune diseases, as well as their potential synergistic effects with conventional antibiotics.
results_summary: All methanolic extracts of Boswellia sacra inhibited bacterial growth, with Najdi oleoresin being the most potent. Combinations with conventional antibiotics showed 38 synergistic and 166 additive effects, particularly with tetracycline. The extracts were nontoxic in cell viability assays.
population_specificity: In vitro study (bacterial pathogens and human cell lines).
interactions: Synergistic effects noted with conventional antibiotics, especially tetracycline.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective effects of Boswellia serrata extract (BSE) against fipronil-induced neurobehavioral toxicity in rats.
results_summary: BSE co-treatment significantly reduced oxidative stress, inflammation, and apoptotic markers while improving neurobehavioral outcomes and histopathological findings in a dose-dependent manner. The higher dose (500 mg/kg BW) showed particularly strong neuroprotective effects.
population_specificity: Male Wistar albino rats.
effective_dosage: 250 mg/kg BW and 500 mg/kg BW, administered orally.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of chronic administration of standardized methanolic extract of Boswellia sacra on blood cell count in experimental animals, particularly focusing on potential haematotoxicity.
results_summary: The study found that Boswellia sacra extract caused hypochromic normocytic anemia in rats at higher doses (500 and 1000 mg/kg), but no other blood parameters were significantly affected. The extract had no impact on behavior, food consumption, or weight gain.
population_specificity: Experimental animals (rats)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Boswellia serrata extract (containing 30% AKBA) combined with enzalutamide synergistically inhibits prostate cancer cell growth and androgen receptor activity, compared to AKBA alone.
results_summary: The combination of Boswellia serrata extract and enzalutamide showed strong synergistic effects, reducing cell viability by 50% at lower enzalutamide doses (6 µM) and intermediate DHT levels (1 nM). The combination also reduced androgen receptor expression, PSA levels, and Pgp expression, outperforming AKBA alone.
population_specificity: LNCaP prostate cancer cells and cells derived from prostate cancer patients.
effective_dosage: Boswellia serrata extract (4.1 µg/ml to 16.4 µg/ml) with enzalutamide (6 µM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of Boswellia serrata resin extract (BSRE) on growth performance, immune response, antioxidant status, and disease resistance in Nile tilapia.
results_summary: BSRE improved growth performance, immune response, antioxidant status, and disease resistance in Nile tilapia, with the 5 g kg-1 dose showing optimal benefits without harmful effects, while higher doses adversely affected organ histoarchitecture.
population_specificity: Nile tilapia (Oreochromis niloticus L.) fingerlings

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a combination supplement containing Boswellia, turmeric, and red algae extracts on knee osteoarthritis symptoms using patient-reported outcome measures.
results_summary: The study found that the supplement combination improved pain relief and functional outcomes in knee osteoarthritis patients, with 64.5% achieving positive symptom relief by Day 90 and reductions in pain intensity and analgesic use. Pain characteristics like "stabbing pain" and "widespread pain" were associated with non-response.
population_specificity: Patients with painful unilateral or bilateral knee osteoarthritis (mean age 62.9 years, 69.5% female).
effective_dosage: 1-4 capsules per day (exact dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential role of a curcumin and boswellia phytosome extract (CBP) in relieving symptoms of symptomatic uncomplicated colonic diverticular disease (SUDD).
results_summary: The study found that CBP supplementation significantly reduced abdominal pain (p<0.0001), with efficacy observed within 10 days and maintained until the 30th day of intervention.
population_specificity: Patients (men and women) with symptomatic uncomplicated colonic diverticular disease (SUDD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to demonstrate the natural occurrence of α-KBA in Boswellia spp., develop a method for its quantification, and evaluate its cytotoxic effects against triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) cell lines.
results_summary: The study identified α-KBA in Boswellia oleogum resins, developed a precise HPLC-MS/MS method for its quantification, and showed that α-KBA exhibits cytotoxicity against TNBC cell lines and induces apoptosis in xenografts, with β-isomers and acetylated forms showing higher efficacy.
population_specificity: In vitro TNBC cell lines (MDA-MB-231 and others) and in vivo xenografts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a food supplement containing Boswellia serrata and Curcuma longa extracts could improve symptoms of tendinopathy when added to standard care.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in pain and functional limitation scores after 1-month treatment, with a 51.6% reduction in both measures. The supplement was well-tolerated, with only 6.5% of patients reporting mild side effects and no severe adverse effects.
population_specificity: 670 patients with tendinopathy recruited by Belgian general practitioners.
effective_dosage: Two tablets twice a day (exact dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects of Boswellia species on metabolic syndrome and related disorders such as hyperglycemia, dyslipidemia, hypertension, and obesity.
results_summary: Boswellia species demonstrated beneficial effects in controlling metabolic syndrome by reducing insulin resistance, restoring pancreatic beta cells, regulating blood pressure, and modulating blood lipid profiles through anti-inflammatory and antioxidant mechanisms. The study confirmed its therapeutic and protective effects on hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and obesity.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review of published evidence up to 2020).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy and safety of frankincense-based sitz-baths on episiotomy wound healing in primiparous women.
results_summary: The study found that frankincense was less effective than myrrh in improving episiotomy wound healing, with no significant difference compared to betadine. The total REEDA score did not show statistical improvement for frankincense over betadine.
population_specificity: Primiparous women with singleton pregnancies after normal vaginal delivery.
effective_dosage: Sitz-bath of frankincense extract twice a day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-inflammatory capacity and medicinal use of Boswellia carteri, specifically its effects on human primary T cells and the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that Boswellia carteri extract suppressed T cell proliferation and cytokine secretion without cytotoxicity, primarily through NFAT-conditioned suppression, with 3-O-acetyl-alpha-boswellic acid identified as the active compound.
population_specificity: Human primary T cells in vitro.
